an4.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vajjīsu viharati bhaṇḍagāme.
an4.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis at Wares Village.

an4.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an4.1:2.1.pli: “Catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
an4.1:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, due to not understanding and not penetrating four things, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.

an4.1:2.3.pli: Ariyassa, bhikkhave, sīlassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

an4.1:2.4.pli: Ariyassa, bhikkhave, samādhissa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

an4.1:2.5.pli: Ariyāya, bhikkhave, paññāya ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

an4.1:2.6.pli: Ariyāya, bhikkhave, vimuttiyā ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

an4.1:2.7.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyaṃ sīlaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, ariyo samādhi anubuddho paṭividdho, ariyā paññā anubuddhā paṭividdhā, ariyā vimutti anubuddhā paṭividdhā, ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, khīṇā bhavanetti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
an4.1:2.7.eng: These noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the leash to existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”

an4.1:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an4.1:3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
an4.1:3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

an4.1:5.1.eng: And so the Buddha, having insight,

an4.1:5.2.eng: explained this teaching to the mendicants.

an4.1:5.3.eng: The teacher made an end of suffering,

an4.1:5.4.eng: seeing clearly, he is fully quenched.”

an4.10:1.3.eng: The yokes of sensual pleasures, future lives, views, and ignorance.

an4.10:1.4.eng: And what is the yoke of sensual pleasures?

an4.10:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kāmānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.10:1.5.eng: It’s when you don’t truly understand sensual pleasures’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

an4.10:1.6.pli: Tassa kāmānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ appajānato yo kāmesu kāmarāgo kāmanandī kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho kāmajjhosānaṃ kāmataṇhā sānuseti.
an4.10:1.6.eng: So greed, relishing, affection, infatuation, thirst, passion, attachment, and craving for sensual pleasures linger on inside.

an4.10:1.7.eng: This is called the yoke of sensual pleasures.

an4.10:1.8.eng: Such is the yoke of sensual pleasures.

an4.10:2.1.eng: And what is the yoke of future lives?

an4.10:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco bhavānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.10:2.2.eng: It’s when you don’t truly understand future lives’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

an4.10:2.3.pli: Tassa bhavānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ appajānato yo bhavesu bhavarāgo bhavanandī bhavasneho bhavamucchā bhavapipāsā bhavapariḷāho bhavajjhosānaṃ bhavataṇhā sānuseti.
an4.10:2.3.eng: So greed, relishing, affection, infatuation, thirst, passion, attachment, and craving for continued existence linger on inside.

an4.10:2.4.eng: This is called the yoke of future lives.

an4.10:2.5.eng: Such are the yokes of sensual pleasures and future lives.

an4.10:3.1.eng: And what is the yoke of views?

an4.10:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco diṭṭhīnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.10:3.2.eng: It’s when you don’t truly understand views’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

an4.10:3.3.pli: Tassa diṭṭhīnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ appajānato yo diṭṭhīsu diṭṭhirāgo diṭṭhinandī diṭṭhisneho diṭṭhimucchā diṭṭhipipāsā diṭṭhipariḷāho diṭṭhijjhosānaṃ diṭṭhitaṇhā sānuseti.
an4.10:3.3.eng: So greed, relishing, affection, infatuation, thirst, passion, attachment, and craving for views linger on inside.

an4.10:3.4.eng: This is called the yoke of views.

an4.10:3.5.eng: Such are the yokes of sensual pleasures, future lives, and views.

an4.10:4.1.eng: And what is the yoke of ignorance?

an4.10:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.10:4.2.eng: It’s when you don’t truly understand the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

an4.10:4.3.pli: Tassa channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ appajānato yā chasu phassāyatanesu avijjā aññāṇaṃ sānuseti.
an4.10:4.3.eng: so ignorance and unknowing of the six fields of contact linger on inside.

an4.10:4.4.eng: This is called the yoke of ignorance.

an4.10:4.5.eng: Such are the yokes of sensual pleasures, future lives, views, and ignorance.

an4.10:4.6.pli: saṃyutto pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi saṅkilesikehi ponobhavikehi sadarehi dukkhavipākehi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇikehi. Tasmā ayogakkhemīti vuccati.
an4.10:4.6.eng: These are bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. That’s why someone yoked to them is called: ‘one who has not found sanctuary from the yoke’.

an4.10:5.1.eng: There are these four kinds of unyoking.

an4.10:5.3.eng: Unyoking from sensual pleasures, future lives, views, and ignorance.

an4.10:5.4.eng: And what is unyoking from sensual pleasures?

an4.10:5.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kāmānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.10:5.5.eng: It’s when you truly understand sensual pleasures’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

an4.10:5.6.pli: Tassa kāmānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānato yo kāmesu kāmarāgo kāmanandī kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho kāmajjhosānaṃ kāmataṇhā sā nānuseti.
an4.10:5.6.eng: So greed, relishing, affection, infatuation, thirst, passion, attachment, and craving for sensual pleasures don’t linger on inside.

an4.10:5.7.eng: This is called unyoking from sensual pleasures.

an4.10:5.8.eng: Such is unyoking from sensual pleasures.

an4.10:6.1.eng: And what is unyoking from future lives?

an4.10:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco bhavānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.10:6.2.eng: It’s when you truly understand future lives’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

an4.10:6.3.pli: Tassa bhavānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānato yo bhavesu bhavarāgo bhavanandī bhavasneho bhavamucchā bhavapipāsā bhavapariḷāho bhavajjhosānaṃ bhavataṇhā sā nānuseti.
an4.10:6.3.eng: So greed, relishing, affection, infatuation, thirst, passion, attachment, and craving for continued existence don’t linger on inside.

an4.10:6.4.eng: This is called unyoking from future lives.

an4.10:6.5.eng: Such is unyoking from sensual pleasures and future lives.

an4.10:7.1.eng: And what is unyoking from views?

an4.10:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco diṭṭhīnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.10:7.2.eng: It’s when you truly understand views’ origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

an4.10:7.3.pli: Tassa diṭṭhīnaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānato yo diṭṭhīsu diṭṭhirāgo diṭṭhinandī diṭṭhisneho diṭṭhimucchā diṭṭhipipāsā diṭṭhipariḷāho diṭṭhijjhosānaṃ diṭṭhitaṇhā sā nānuseti.
an4.10:7.3.eng: So greed, relishing, affection, infatuation, thirst, passion, attachment, and craving for views don’t linger on inside.

an4.10:7.4.eng: This is called unyoking from views.

an4.10:7.5.eng: Such is unyoking from sensual pleasures, future lives, and views.

an4.10:8.1.eng: And what is unyoking from ignorance?

an4.10:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.10:8.2.eng: It’s when you truly understand the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

an4.10:8.3.pli: Tassa channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānato yā chasu phassāyatanesu avijjā aññāṇaṃ sā nānuseti.
an4.10:8.3.eng: so ignorance and unknowing of the six fields of contact don’t linger on inside.

an4.10:8.4.eng: This is called unyoking from ignorance.

an4.10:8.5.eng: Such is unyoking from sensual pleasures, future lives, views, and ignorance.

an4.10:8.6.pli: visaṃyutto pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi saṅkilesikehi ponobhavikehi sadarehi dukkhavipākehi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇikehi. Tasmā yogakkhemīti vuccati.
an4.10:8.6.eng: These are bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. That’s why someone unyoked from them is called: ‘one who has found sanctuary from the yoke’.

an4.10:8.7.eng: These are the four kinds of unyoking.

an4.10:9.2.eng: and the desire to be reborn in a future life;

an4.10:10.3.eng: But those who fully understand sensual pleasures,

an4.10:10.4.eng: and the yoke to all future lives;

an4.10:11.1.eng: with the yoke of views eradicated,

an4.10:11.4.eng: truly those sages have slipped their yoke.”

an4.100:1.1.pli: Atha kho potaliyo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.100:1.1.eng: Then the wanderer Potaliya went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.100:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho potaliyaṃ paribbājakaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an4.100:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the Buddha said to him:

an4.100:2.1.eng: “Potaliya, these four individuals are found in the world.

an4.100:2.3.pli: Idha, potaliya, ekacco puggalo avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca kho vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.
an4.100:2.3.eng: One individual criticizes those deserving of criticism at the right time, truthfully and correctly. But they don’t praise those deserving of praise at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an4.100:2.4.pli: Idha pana, potaliya, ekacco puggalo vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca kho avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.
an4.100:2.4.eng: Another individual praises those deserving of praise … But they don’t criticize those deserving of criticism …

an4.100:2.5.pli: Idha pana, potaliya, ekacco puggalo neva avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.
an4.100:2.5.eng: Another individual doesn’t praise those deserving of praise … Nor do they criticize those deserving of criticism …

an4.100:2.6.pli: Idha pana, potaliya, ekacco puggalo avaṇṇārahassa ca avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, vaṇṇārahassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.
an4.100:2.6.eng: Another individual criticizes those deserving of criticism at the right time, truthfully and correctly. And they praise those deserving of praise at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an4.100:2.7.pli: Ime kho, potaliya, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.100:2.7.eng: These are the four individuals found in the world.

an4.100:2.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, potaliya, catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ katamo te puggalo khamati abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro cā”ti?
an4.100:2.8.eng: Of these four individuals, who do you believe to be the finest?”

an4.100:3.1.pli: “Cattārome, bho gotama, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.

an4.100:3.3.pli: Idha, bho gotama, ekacco puggalo avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca kho vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.

an4.100:3.4.pli: Idha pana, bho gotama, ekacco puggalo vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca kho avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.

an4.100:3.5.pli: Idha pana, bho gotama, ekacco puggalo neva avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.

an4.100:3.6.pli: Idha pana, bho gotama, ekacco puggalo avaṇṇārahassa ca avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, vaṇṇārahassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.

an4.100:3.7.pli: Ime kho, bho gotama, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.

an4.100:3.8.pli: Imesaṃ, bho gotama, catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ yvāyaṃ puggalo neva avaṇṇārahassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, no ca vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena;
an4.100:3.8.eng: “Mister Gotama, of these four individuals, it is the individual who neither praises those deserving of praise at the right time, truthfully and correctly; nor criticizes those deserving of criticism at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an4.100:3.9.pli: ayaṃ me puggalo khamati imesaṃ catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca.
an4.100:3.9.eng: That is the individual I believe to be the finest.

an4.100:3.11.pli: Abhikkantā hesā, bho gotama, yadidaṃ upekkhā”ti.
an4.100:3.11.eng: Because, worthy Gotama, equanimity is the best.”

an4.100:4.2.pli: Katame cattāro …pe… ime kho, potaliya, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.

an4.100:4.3.pli: Imesaṃ kho, potaliya, catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ yvāyaṃ puggalo avaṇṇārahassa ca avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, vaṇṇārahassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā hoti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena;
an4.100:4.3.eng: “Potaliya, of these four individuals, it is the individual who criticizes those deserving of criticism at the right time, truthfully and correctly; and praises those deserving of praise at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an4.100:4.4.pli: ayaṃ imesaṃ catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca.
an4.100:4.4.eng: That is the individual I consider to be the finest.

an4.100:4.6.pli: Abhikkantā hesā, potaliya, yadidaṃ tattha tattha kālaññutā”ti.
an4.100:4.6.eng: Because, Potaliya, understanding of time and context is the best.”

an4.100:5.1.pli: “Cattārome, bho gotama, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.

an4.100:5.2.pli: Katame cattāro …pe… ime kho, bho gotama, cattāro puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.

an4.100:5.3.pli: Imesaṃ, bho gotama, catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ yvāyaṃ puggalo avaṇṇārahassa ca avaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena, vaṇṇārahassa ca vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitā bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena;
an4.100:5.3.eng: “Mister Gotama, of these four individuals, it is the individual who criticizes those deserving of criticism at the right time, truthfully and correctly; and praises those deserving of praise at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an4.100:5.4.pli: ayaṃ me puggalo khamati imesaṃ catunnaṃ puggalānaṃ abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca.
an4.100:5.4.eng: That is the individual I believe to be the finest.

an4.100:5.6.pli: Abhikkantā hesā, bho gotama, yadidaṃ tattha tattha kālaññutā.
an4.100:5.6.eng: Because, worthy Gotama, understanding of time and context is the best.

an4.100:6.1.pli: Abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama.

an4.100:6.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
an4.100:6.2.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

an4.100:6.3.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
an4.100:6.3.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

an4.100:6.4.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an4.100:6.4.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an4.101:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an4.101:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an4.101:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an4.101:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of clouds.

an4.101:2.5.eng: one neither thunders nor rains, and

an4.101:2.7.eng: These are the four kinds of clouds.

an4.101:2.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cattāro valāhakūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.101:2.8.eng: In the same way, these four individuals similar to clouds are found in the world.

an4.101:2.12.eng: one neither thunders nor rains, and

an4.101:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā hoti no vassitā?
an4.101:3.1.eng: And how does an individual thunder but not rain?

an4.101:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo bhāsitā hoti, no kattā.
an4.101:3.2.eng: It’s when an individual is a talker, not a doer.

an4.101:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā hoti, no vassitā.
an4.101:3.3.eng: That’s how an individual thunders but doesn’t rain.

an4.101:3.4.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako gajjitā, no vassitā;
an4.101:3.4.eng: That individual is like a cloud that thunders but doesn’t rain, I say.

an4.101:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo vassitā hoti, no gajjitā?
an4.101:4.1.eng: And how does an individual rain but not thunder?

an4.101:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo kattā hoti, no bhāsitā.
an4.101:4.2.eng: It’s when an individual is a doer, not a talker. …

an4.101:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo vassitā hoti, no gajjitā.

an4.101:4.4.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako vassitā, no gajjitā;

an4.101:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo neva gajjitā hoti, no vassitā?
an4.101:5.1.eng: And how does an individual neither thunder nor rain?

an4.101:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo neva bhāsitā hoti, no kattā.
an4.101:5.2.eng: It’s when an individual is neither a talker nor a doer. …

an4.101:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo neva gajjitā hoti, no vassitā.

an4.101:5.4.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako neva gajjitā, no vassitā;

an4.101:6.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā ca hoti vassitā ca?
an4.101:6.1.eng: And how does an individual both thunder and rain?

an4.101:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo bhāsitā ca hoti kattā ca.
an4.101:6.2.eng: It’s when an individual is both a talker and a doer. …

an4.101:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā ca hoti vassitā ca.

an4.101:6.4.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako gajjitā ca vassitā ca;

an4.101:6.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro valāhakūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.101:6.6.eng: These four individuals similar to clouds are found in the world.”

an4.102:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of clouds.

an4.102:1.5.eng: one neither thunders nor rains, and

an4.102:1.7.eng: These are the four kinds of clouds.

an4.102:1.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cattāro valāhakūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.102:1.8.eng: In the same way, these four individuals similar to clouds are found in the world.

an4.102:1.12.eng: one neither thunders nor rains, and

an4.102:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā hoti, no vassitā?
an4.102:2.1.eng: And how does an individual thunder but not rain?

an4.102:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.102:2.2.eng: It’s when an individual memorizes the teaching—

an4.102:2.3.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an4.102:2.3.eng: statements, mixed prose and verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an4.102:2.4.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.102:2.4.eng: But they don’t truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an4.102:2.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā hoti, no vassitā.
an4.102:2.5.eng: That’s how an individual thunders but doesn’t rain.

an4.102:2.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako gajjitā, no vassitā;
an4.102:2.6.eng: That individual is like a cloud that thunders but doesn’t rain, I say.

an4.102:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo vassitā hoti, no gajjitā?
an4.102:3.1.eng: And how does an individual rain but not thunder?

an4.102:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo dhammaṃ na pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.102:3.2.eng: It’s when an individual doesn’t memorize the teaching …

an4.102:3.3.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.

an4.102:3.4.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.102:3.4.eng: But they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ …

an4.102:3.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo vassitā hoti, no gajjitā.

an4.102:3.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako vassitā, no gajjitā;

an4.102:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo neva gajjitā hoti, no vassitā?
an4.102:4.1.eng: And how does an individual neither thunder nor rain?

an4.102:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo neva dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.102:4.2.eng: It’s when an individual doesn’t memorize the teaching …

an4.102:4.3.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.

an4.102:4.4.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.102:4.4.eng: Nor do they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ …

an4.102:4.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo neva gajjitā hoti, no vassitā.

an4.102:4.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako neva gajjitā, no vassitā;

an4.102:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā ca hoti vassitā ca?
an4.102:5.1.eng: And how does an individual both thunder and rain?

an4.102:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇāti—
an4.102:5.2.eng: It’s when an individual memorizes the teaching …

an4.102:5.3.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.

an4.102:5.4.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.102:5.4.eng: And they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ …

an4.102:5.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo gajjitā ca hoti vassitā ca.

an4.102:5.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, valāhako gajjitā ca vassitā ca;

an4.102:5.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro valāhakūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.102:5.8.eng: These four individuals similar to clouds are found in the world.”

an4.103:1.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cattāro kumbhūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an4.103:1.8.eng: In the same way, these four individuals similar to pots are found in the world.

an4.103:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo tuccho hoti pihito?
an4.103:2.1.eng: And how is a individual covered but hollow?

an4.103:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa pāsādikaṃ hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ.
an4.103:2.2.eng: It’s when an individual is impressive when going out and coming back, when looking ahead and aside, when bending and extending the limbs, and when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes.

an4.103:2.3.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.103:2.3.eng: But they don’t truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an4.103:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo tuccho hoti pihito.
an4.103:2.4.eng: That’s how an individual is covered but hollow.

an4.103:2.5.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, kumbho tuccho pihito;
an4.103:2.5.eng: That individual is like a pot that’s covered but hollow, I say.

an4.103:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo pūro hoti vivaṭo?
an4.103:3.1.eng: And how is a individual uncovered but full?

an4.103:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa na pāsādikaṃ hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ.
an4.103:3.2.eng: It’s when an individual is not impressive …

an4.103:3.3.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.103:3.3.eng: But they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ …

an4.103:3.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo pūro hoti vivaṭo.

an4.103:3.5.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, kumbho pūro vivaṭo;

an4.103:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo tuccho hoti vivaṭo?
an4.103:4.1.eng: And how is a individual uncovered and hollow?

an4.103:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa na pāsādikaṃ hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ.
an4.103:4.2.eng: It’s when an individual is not impressive …

an4.103:4.3.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an4.103:4.3.eng: Nor do they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ …

an4.103:4.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo tuccho hoti vivaṭo.

an4.103:4.5.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, kumbho tuccho vivaṭo;

an4.103:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, puggalo pūro hoti pihito?
an4.103:5.1.eng: And how is a individual covered and full?

an4.103:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa pāsādikaṃ hoti abhikkantaṃ paṭikkantaṃ ālokitaṃ vilokitaṃ samiñjitaṃ pasāritaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇaṃ.
an4.103:5.2.eng: It’s when an individual is impressive …

an4.103:5.3.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.103:5.3.eng: And they truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ …

an4.103:5.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, puggalo pūro hoti pihito.

an4.103:5.5.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, kumbho pūro pihito;

an4.103:5.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro kumbhūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an4.103:5.7.eng: These four individuals similar to pots are found in the world.”
